axe Definition from Wiktionary, the free dictionary Jump to navigation Jump to search See also: Axe and axé Contents English 1.1 Etymology 1.1.1 Alternative forms 1.1.2 Pronunciation 1.1.3 Noun 1.1.3.1 Usage notes 1.1.3.2 Derived terms 1.1.3.3 Translations 1.1.3.4 See also 1.1.4 Verb 1.1.4.1 Translations 1.2 Etymology 1.2.1 Alternative forms 1.2.2 Noun 1.2.3 Verb 1.3 Etymology 1.3.1 Verb 1.4 Further reading 1.5 Anagrams French 2.1 Etymology 2.2 Pronunciation 2.3 Noun 2.4 Further reading Galician 3.1 Etymology 3.2 Pronunciation 3.3 Noun 3.4 References Interlingua 4.1 Noun Latin 5.1 Noun Middle English 6.1 Etymology 6.1.1 Noun 6.2 Etymology 6.2.1 Alternative forms 6.2.2 Pronunciation 6.2.3 Noun 6.2.3.1 Descendants 6.2.3.2 References 6.3 Etymology 6.3.1 Noun 6.4 Etymology 6.4.1 Verb English edit Etymology edit An axe From Middle English ax axe ex from Old English æx from Proto- Germanic akwisī probably from Proto-Indo-European h₂egʷsih₂ “axe” from h₂eḱ- “sharp, pointed” Compare German Axt Danish økse Icelandic öxi and also Latin ascia.
Alternative forms edit ax largely US Pronunciation edit enPR: ăks, IPA key /æks/ Audio US file ---|---|--- Rhymes: -æks Noun edit axe plural axes 1.
tool for felling trees or chopping wood etc. consisting of heavy head flattened to blade on one side, and handle attached to it.
An ancient weapon consisting of head that has one or two blades and long handle.
3. informal dismissal or rejection.
Synonyms: chop, pink slip, sack, boot His girlfriend/boss/schoolmaster gave him the axe. 1975 Bob Dylan lyrics and music “Tangled Up in Blue”, in Blood on the Tracks: had job in the great North Woods Workin' as cook for spell But never did like it all that much/ And one day the axe just fell 4. slang, music gigging musician's particular instrument, especially guitar in rock music or saxophone in jazz.
5. finance position, interest, or reason in buying and selling stock, often with ulterior motives.
financial dealer has an axe in stock that his buyers don't know about, giving him an advantage in making the most profit. Usage notes edit In the United States, this spelling is sometimes used to distinguish the weapon from the tool, though most people use either ax or less commonly axe for both senses.
Numbers do not necessarily match those in definitions.
See instructions atWiktionary:Entry layoutTranslations. Translations to be checked Cherokee: please verify ᎦᎷᏯᏍᏘ galuyasti Erzya: please verify узере uzere Interlingua: please verify hacha Malayalam: please verify മഴു ml maḻu Maori: please verify toki Romanian: please verify topor ro n, please verify secure ro Tupinambá: please verify îy Turkish: please verify balta tr ---|---|--- See also edit adze hatchet twibill Verb edit axe third-person singular simple present axes present participle axing simple past and past participle axed 1. transitive To fell or chop with an axe.
2. transitive, figuratively To lay off, terminate or drastically reduce, especially in rough or ruthless manner; to cancel.
Synonyms: fire, lay off, downsize, cancel The government announced its plans to axe public spending. The broadcaster axed the series because far fewer people than expected watched it. He got axed in the last round of firings. 2020 February 12, Mark Sweney, “Mobile World Congress axed after firms quit over coronavirus fears”, in The Guardian On Wednesday, GSMA, which organises the congress, was forced to admit it would have to axe this year’s event after more than 40 companies pulled out citing health and safety concerns.
Translations edit fell or chop Bulgarian: отсичам брадва otsičam bradva Czech: porazit cs to fell tree osekávat, otesávat Estonian: raiuma Greek: τσεκουρώνω el tsekouróno πελεκώ el pelekó κόβω el kóvo Latvian: cirst Mongolian: сүхдэх mn sühdeh Russian: руби́ть ru impf rubítʹ поруби́ть ru pf porubítʹ Swahili: shoka sw Swedish: fälla sv fell tree hugga sv yxa sv chop ---|---|--- terminate or reduce tremendously in rough or ruthless manner Chinese: Mandarin: 腰斩 zh yāozhǎn Greek: περικόπτω el perikópto τσεκουρώνω el tsekouróno Japanese: 打ち切る uchikiru Swahili: shoka sw Yiddish: אונטערהאַקן unterhakn ---|---|--- Etymology edit Alternative forms edit ax American Noun edit axe plural axes 1. archaic The axle of wheel.
Verb edit axe third-person singular simple present axes present participle axing simple past and past participle axed 1.
To furnish with an axle.
Etymology edit See ax aks.
Verb edit axe third-person singular simple present axes present participle axing simple past and past participle axed 1. now obsolete outside dialects, especially African-American Vernacular Alternative form of ask 1395 John Wycliffe, trans.
Bible Corinthis 14:35: But if thei wolen ony thing lerne, at home axe thei her hosebondis; for it is foule thing to womman to speke in chirche.
1526 William Tyndale, trans.
Bible Luke IIi: And the people axed hym, sayinge: What shall we do then.
Further reading edit axe disambiguation on Wikipedia.Wikipedia Anagrams edit exa- French edit Etymology edit Borrowed from Latin axis.
Compare the inherited doublet ais.
Pronunciation edit IPA key /aks/ audio| file ---|---|--- Noun edit axe plural axes 1. axis 2. axle Further reading edit “axe” in Trésor de la langue française informatisé The Digitized Treasury of the French Language Galician edit Etymology edit Unknown.
Cognate with Spanish aje.

Interlingua edit Noun edit axe plural axes 1.
An axis, straight line that crosses the center of body and around which it turns.
An axle, bar connecting parallel wheels of kart, wagon, etc. Latin edit Noun edit axe 1. ablative singular of axis Middle English edit Etymology edit From Old English æx.
Noun edit axe 1.
